chapter.title: Where To Go From Here
chapter.para: OpenIDM can do much more than reconcile data between two different sources. In this chapter, you will read about the key features of OpenIDM, with links to additional information about each feature.

section.title: Integrating Business Processes and Workflows
section.para: A business process begins with an objective and includes a well-defined sequence of tasks to meet that objective. In OpenIDM, you can configure many of these tasks as self-service workflows, such as self-registration, new user onboarding, and account certification.
With OpenIDM, you can automate many of these tasks as a workflow.
Once you configure the right workflows, a newly-hired engineer can log into OpenIDM and request access to manufacturing information.
That request is sent to the appropriate manager for approval. Once approved, the OpenIDM provisions the new engineer with access to manufacturing.
OpenIDM supports workflow-driven provisioning activities, based on the embedded Activiti Process Engine, which complies with the Business Process Model and Notation 2.0 (BPMN 2.0) standard.

OpenIDM integrates additional workflows such as new user onboarding, orphan account detection, and password change reminders. For more information, see the section in the Integrator's Guide on
Workflow Use Cases.

section.title: Managing User Roles
section.para: Some users need accounts on multiple systems. For example, insurance agents may also have insurance policies with the company that they work for. In that situation, the insurance agent is also a customer of the company.
Alternatively, a salesperson may also test customer engineering scenarios. That salesperson may also need access to engineering systems.

In OpenIDM, each of these user scenarios is known as a role. OpenIDM allows you to set up a consolidated set of attributes associated with each role. To do so, you would configure custom roles to assign to selected users. For example, you may assign both insured and agent roles to an agent, while assigning the insured role to all customers.
In a similar fashion, OpenIDM allows you to assign both sales and engineering roles to the sales engineer.
You can then synchronize users with those roles into appropriate data stores.

For more information, read the OpenIDM Integrator's Guide section on
Configuring Custom Roles. For a sample of how you can configure external roles within OpenIDM, see the description of
Configuring OpenIDM for Roles and Provisioning.

section.title: Connecting to Remote Data Stores
section.para: You can use OpenIDM to connect to a substantial variety user and device data stores, on premise and in the cloud. While OpenIDM can connect to some connectors dedicated to a few data stores, OpenIDM can also connect to many more data stores using a scripted connector framework.

itemizedlist.para: OpenIDM includes support for connectors to the following external resources:

listitem.para:
Generic LDAP, which supports connections to a variety of LDAP directories, including
OpenDJ and Active Directory

section.para: If the resource that you need is not on the list, you should be able to use one of the OpenIDM scripted connector frameworks to connect to that resource.

listitem.para:
For connectors associated with Microsoft Windows, OpenIDM includes a
PowerShell Connector Toolkit that you can use to provision a variety of Microsoft services, including but not limited to Active Directory, SQL Server, Microsoft Exchange, SharePoint, Office 365, and Azure Active Directory. OpenIDM includes a sample PowerShell Connector Toolkit configuration in the OpenIDM Installation Guide.

For other external resources, OpenIDM includes a Groovy Connector Toolkit that allows you to run Groovy scripts to interact with any external resource. The
OpenIDM Installation Guide includes samples of how you might implement the scripted Groovy connector.

section.title: Reconciliation
section.para: OpenIDM supports reconciliation between two data stores, as a source and a target.
In identity management, reconciliation compares the contents of objects in different data stores, and makes decisions based on configurable policies.
For example, if you have an application that maintains its own user store, OpenIDM can ensure your canonical directory attributes are kept up to date by reconciling their values as they are changed.

For more information, see the following chapter on
Configuring Synchronization.

section.title: Authentication Modules Available for OpenIDM
section.para:
OpenIDM has access to several different authentication modules that can help you protect your systems. For more information, see the following section of the Integrator's Guide:
Supported Authentication and Session Modules.

section.title: Finding Additional Use Cases
section.para: OpenIDM is a lightweight and highly customizable identity management product.
The OpenIDM documentation includes additional use cases. Most of them are known as Samples, shown in the OpenIDM Installation Guide.

These samples include step-by-step instructions on how you can connect to different data stores, customize product behavior using JavaScript and Groovy, and administer OpenIDM with ForgeRock's commons RESTful API commands.

section.title: How OpenIDM Can Help Your Organization
section.para: Now that you have gotten a taste for how OpenIDM can help you manage users, review the features that OpenIDM can bring to your organization.

listitem.para: Configure OpenIDM with the Web-Based Administrative User Interface. You can configure many major components of OpenIDM without ever touching a text configuration file.

User self-service features can streamline onboarding, new user registration, and account certification. OpenIDM self-service features are built upon a
BPMN 2.0-compliant workflow engine.
Create and manage users based on attributes such as organizational need, job function, and geographic location.

Choose the desired backend database for your deployment. OpenIDM supports MySQL, Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle Database, and PostgreSQL. For the latest versions, see the following chapter of the Release Notes:
Before You Install OpenIDM.
Set up fine-grained control of passwords to ensure consistent password policies across all applications and data stores. Support password synchronization over an encrypted connection.
OpenIDM logs all activity, internally and within connected systems. With such logs, you can track information for account changes, access requests and more.
OpenIDM can access a generic scripted connector that allows you to set up communications with many external data stores.
